summary.para: Associates the specified input context with the specified window. By default, the operating system associates the default input context with each window as it is created. Note To specify a type of association, the application should use the function.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to the window to associate with the input context.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context. If hIMC is NULL, the function removes any association the window has with an input context. Thus IME cannot be used in the window.

returns.para: Returns the handle to the input context previously associated with the window.

remarks.para: When associating an input context with a window, an application must remove the association before destroying the input context. One way to do this is to save the handle and reassociate it to the default input context with the window.

summary.para: Changes the association between the input method context and the specified window or its children.

param.name: unnamedParam1
param.para: Handle to the window to associate with the input context.

param.name: unnamedParam2
param.para: Handle to the input method context.

param.name: unnamedParam3
param.para: Flags specifying the type of association between the window and the input method context. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Associate the input method context to the child windows of the specified window only.
Restore the default input method context of the window.
Do not associate the input method context with windows that are not associated with any input method context.

returns.para: Returns TRUE if successful or FALSE otherwise.

remarks.para: If the application calls this function with IACE_CHILDREN, the operating system associates the specified input method context with child windows of the window indicated by hWnd. It associates the input method context only with child windows of the thread that creates hWnd. Any child window that is created after this function has been called will not be affected. Instead, the default input method context will be associated with it.
If the application calls this function with IACE_DEFAULT, the operating system restores the default input method context for the window. In this case, the hIMC parameter is ignored.

summary.para: Displays the configuration dialog box for the IME of the specified input locale identifier.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier of an IME.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to the parent window for the dialog box.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Flags specifying the type of dialog box to display. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Display general-purpose configuration dialog box.
Display register word dialog box.
Display dictionary selection dialog box.

param.name: LPVOID
param.para: Pointer to supplemental data. If dwMode is set to IME_CONFIG_REGISTERWORD, this parameter must indicate a structure. If dwMode is not IME_CONFIG_REGISTERWORD, this parameter is ignored.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmConfigureIME as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Creates a new input context, allocating memory for the context and initializing it. An application calls this function to prepare its own input context.

returns.para: Returns the handle to the new input context if successful, or NULL otherwise.

summary.para: Releases the input context and frees associated memory.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context to free.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: Any application that creates an input context by using the function must call this function to free the context before it terminates. However, before calling ImmDestroyContext, the application must remove the input context from any association with windows in the thread by using the function.

summary.para: Disables the IME for a thread or for all threads in a process.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Identifier of the thread for which to disable the IME. The thread must be in the same process as the application calling this function. The application sets this parameter to 0 to disable the IME for the current thread. The application specifies -1 to disable the IME for all threads in the current process.

returns.para: Returns TRUE if successful or FALSE otherwise.

remarks.para: The application must call this function before the first top-level window in the thread receives the WM_CREATE message. Thus, the application must call this function in one of the following places:

item.description: Any time before calling to create the first top-level window
In the WM_NCCREATE handler for first top-level window

summary.para: Indicates that this thread is a Windows Store app UI thread.

returns.para: Returns TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

remarks.para: Windows Store app brokers such as explorer.exe should call this function in Windows Store app UI threads to ensure that only IMEs that are compatible with Windows Store apps are made available. Those Windows Store app threads that don't require IME input should call to disable IMM entirely for that thread.
The app must call this function before the first top-level window in the thread receives the WM_CREATE message. Thus, the app must call this function in one of the following places:

item.description: Any time before is called to create the first top-level window.
In the WM_NCCREATE handler for the first top-level window.

summary.para: Retrieves the input context for the specified thread.

param.name: idThread
param.para: Identifier for the thread. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Current thread.
Current process.
Identifier of the thread for which to enumerate the context. This thread identifier can belong to another process.

param.name: lpfn
param.para: Pointer to the enumeration callback function. For more information, see EnumInputContext.

param.name: lParam
param.para: Application-supplied data. The function passes this data to the callback function.

returns.para: Returns TRUE if successful or FALSE otherwise.

remarks.para: This function calls the application callback function for each enumerated input context, and passes the specified lParam value.

summary.para: Enumerates the register strings having the specified reading string, style, and register string.

param.name: unnamedParam1
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: unnamedParam2
param.para: Pointer to the callback function. For more information, see EnumRegisterWordProc.

param.name: lpszReading
param.para: Pointer to the reading string to enumerate. The application sets this parameter to NULL if the function is to enumerate all available reading strings that match the dwStyle and lpszRegister settings.

param.name: unnamedParam4
param.para: Style to enumerate. The application specifies 0 if the function is to enumerate all available styles that match the lpszReading and lpszRegister settings.

param.name: lpszRegister
param.para: Pointer to the register string to enumerate. The application sets this parameter to NULL if the function is to enumerate all register strings that match the lpszReading and dwStyle settings.

param.name: unnamedParam6
param.para: Pointer to application-supplied data. The function passes this data to the callback function.

returns.para: Returns the last value returned by the callback function, with the meaning defined by the application. The function returns 0 if it cannot enumerate the register strings.

remarks.para: If dwStyle is set to 0 and both lpszReading and lpszRegister are set to NULL, this function enumerates all register strings in the IME dictionary.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmEnumRegisterWord as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Accesses capabilities of particular IMEs that are not available through other IME API functions. This function is used mainly for country-specific operations.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: UINT
param.para: Index of the operations. For more information, see IME Escapes.

param.name: LPVOID
param.para: Pointer to the data required for the escape specified in uEscape. On output, this parameter indicates the result of the escape. For more information, see IME Escapes.

returns.para: Returns an operation-specific value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

summary.para: Retrieves a candidate list.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: deIndex
param.para: Zero-based index of the candidate list.

param.name: lpCandList
param.para: Pointer to a structure in which the function retrieves the candidate list.

param.name: dwBufLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the buffer to receive the candidate list. The application can specify 0 for this parameter if the function is to return the required size of the output buffer only.

returns.para: Returns the number of bytes copied to the candidate list buffer if successful. If the application has supplied 0 for the dwBufLen parameter, the function returns the size required for the candidate list buffer.
The function returns 0 if it does not succeed.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetCandidateList as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Retrieves information about the composition string.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Index of the information to retrieve, which is one of the values specified in IME Composition String Values. For each value except GCS_CURSORPOS and GCS_DELTASTART, the function copies the requested information to the output buffer. The function returns the cursor and delta position values in the low 16 bits of the return value.

param.name: lpBuf
param.para: Pointer to a buffer in which the function retrieves the composition string information.

param.name: dwBufLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the output buffer, even if the output is a Unicode string. The application sets this parameter to 0 if the function is to return the size of the required output buffer.

returns.para: Returns the number of bytes copied to the output buffer. If dwBufLen is set to 0, the function returns the buffer size, in bytes, required to receive all requested information, excluding the terminating null character. The return value is always the size, in bytes, even if the requested data is a Unicode string.
This function returns one of the following negative error codes if it does not succeed:

item.description: IMM_ERROR_NODATA. Composition data is not ready in the input context.
IMM_ERROR_GENERAL. General error detected by IME.

remarks.para: An application calls this function in response to the WM_IME_COMPOSITION or WM_IME_STARTCOMPOSITION message. The IMM removes the information when the application calls the function.
Note You must write code to handle both full-width Hiragana and half-width Katakana if your application is used with the Soft Input Panel (SIP).

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetCompositionString as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Returns the input context associated with the specified window.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to the window for which to retrieve the input context.

returns.para: Returns the handle to the input context.

remarks.para: An application should routinely use this function to retrieve the current input context before attempting to access information in the context.
The application must call when it is finished with the input context.

summary.para: Retrieves the conversion result list of characters or words without generating any IME-related messages.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: lpSrc
param.para: Pointer to a null-terminated character string specifying the source of the list.

param.name: lpDst
param.para: Pointer to a structure in which the function retrieves the list.

param.name: dwBufLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the output buffer. The application sets this parameter to 0 if the function is to return the buffer size required for the complete conversion result list.

param.name: uFlag
param.para: Action flag. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Source string is the reading string. The function copies the result string to the destination buffer.
Source string is the result string. The function copies the reading string to the destination buffer.
Source string is the result string. The function returns the size, in bytes, of the reading string created if GCL_REVERSECONVERSION is specified.

returns.para: Returns the number of bytes copied to the output buffer. If the application sets the dwBufLen parameter to 0, the function returns the size, in bytes, of the required output buffer.

summary.para: Retrieves the current conversion status.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context for which to retrieve status information.

param.name: lpfdwConversion
param.para: Pointer to a variable in which the function retrieves a combination of conversion mode values. For more information, see IME Conversion Mode Values.

param.name: lpfdwSentence
param.para: Pointer to a variable in which the function retrieves a sentence mode value. For more information, see IME Sentence Mode Values.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: Conversion and sentence mode values are set only if the IME supports those modes.

summary.para: Retrieves the default window handle to the IME class.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to the window.

returns.para: Returns the default window handle to the IME class if successful, or NULL otherwise.

remarks.para: The operating system creates a default IME window for every thread. The window is created based on the IME class. The application can send the WM_IME_CONTROL message to this window.

summary.para: Copies the description of the IME to the specified buffer.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: lpszDescription
param.para: Pointer to a buffer in which the function retrieves the null-terminated string describing the IME.

param.name: uBufLen
param.para: Size, in characters, of the output buffer. The application sets this parameter to 0 if the function is to return the buffer size needed for the complete description, excluding the terminating null character.

Windows NT, Windows 2000, Windows XP: The size of the buffer is in Unicode characters, each consisting of two bytes. If the parameter is set to 0, the function returns the size of the buffer required in Unicode characters, excluding the Unicode terminating null character.

returns.para: Returns the number of characters copied to the output buffer. If the application sets the uBufLen parameter to 0, the function returns the size of the buffer required to receive the description. Neither value includes the terminating null character. For Unicode, the function returns the number of Unicode characters, not including the Unicode terminating null character.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetDescription as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Retrieves information about errors. Applications use the information for user notifications.

param.name: unnamedParam1
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: dwIndex
param.para: Type of guideline information to retrieve. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Return the error level.
Return the error index.
Return the error message string.
Return information about reverse conversion.

param.name: lpBuf
param.para: Pointer to a buffer in which the function retrieves the error message string. This parameter contains NULL if dwIndex is not GGL_STRING or GGL_PRIVATE or if dwBufLen is set to 0.

param.name: dwBufLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the output buffer. The application sets this parameter to 0 if the function is to return the buffer size needed to receive the error message string, not including the terminating null character.

returns.para: Returns an error level, an error index, or the size of an error message string, depending on the value of the dwIndex parameter. If dwIndex is GGL_LEVEL, the return is one of the following values.

item.description: GL_LEVEL_ERROR
Error. The IME might not be able to continue.
GL_LEVEL_FATAL
Fatal error. The IME cannot continue, and data might be lost.
GL_LEVEL_INFORMATION
No error. Information is available for the user.
GL_LEVEL_NOGUIDELINE
No error. Remove previous error message if still visible.
GL_LEVEL_WARNING
Unexpected input or other result. The user should be warned, but the IME can continue.

returns.para: If dwIndex is GGL_INDEX, the return value is one of the following values.

item.description: GL_ID_CANNOTSAVE
The dictionary or the statistics data cannot be saved.
GL_ID_NOCONVERT
The IME cannot convert any more.
GL_ID_NODICTIONARY
The IME cannot find the dictionary, or the dictionary has an unexpected format.
GL_ID_NOMODULE
The IME cannot find the module that is needed.
GL_ID_READINGCONFLICT
A reading conflict occurred. For example, some vowels cannot be put together to form one character.
GL_ID_TOOMANYSTROKE
There are too many strokes for one character or one clause.
GL_ID_TYPINGERROR
Typing error. The IME cannot handle this typing.
GL_ID_UNKNOWN
Unknown error. Refer to the error message string.
GL_ID_INPUTREADING
The IME is accepting reading character input from the end user.
GL_ID_INPUTRADICAL
The IME is accepting radical character input from the end user.
GL_ID_INPUTCODE
The IME is accepting character code input from the end user.
GL_ID_CHOOSECANDIDATE
The IME is accepting candidate string selection from the end user.
GL_ID_REVERSECONVERSION
Information about reverse conversion is available by calling ImmGetGuideLine, specifying GGL_PRIVATE. The information retrieved is in format.

returns.para: If dwIndex is GGL_STRING, the return value is the number of bytes of the string copied to the buffer. However, if dwBufLen is 0, the return value is the buffer size needed to receive the string, not including the terminating null character. For Unicode, if dwBufLen is 0, the return value is the size, in bytes not including the Unicode terminating null character.

If dwIndex is GGL_PRIVATE, the return value is the number of bytes of information copied to the buffer. If dwIndex is GGL_PRIVATE and dwBufLen is 0, the return value is the buffer size needed to receive the information.

remarks.para: Applications typically call this function after receiving an IMN_GUIDELINE command.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetGuideLine as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

param.para: Pointer to a buffer in which the function retrieves the error message string. This parameter contains NULL if dwIndex is not GGL_STRING or GGL_PRIVATE or if dwBufLen is set to 0.

param.name: dwBufLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the output buffer. The application sets this parameter to 0 if the function is to return the buffer size needed to receive the error message string, not including the terminating null character.

returns.para: Returns an error level, an error index, or the size of an error message string, depending on the value of the dwIndex parameter. If dwIndex is GGL_LEVEL, the return is one of the following values.

item.description: GL_LEVEL_ERROR
Error. The IME might not be able to continue.
GL_LEVEL_FATAL
Fatal error. The IME cannot continue, and data might be lost.
GL_LEVEL_INFORMATION
No error. Information is available for the user.
GL_LEVEL_NOGUIDELINE
No error. Remove previous error message if still visible.
GL_LEVEL_WARNING
Unexpected input or other result. The user should be warned, but the IME can continue.

returns.para: If dwIndex is GGL_INDEX, the return value is one of the following values.

item.description: GL_ID_CANNOTSAVE
The dictionary or the statistics data cannot be saved.
GL_ID_NOCONVERT
The IME cannot convert any more.
GL_ID_NODICTIONARY
The IME cannot find the dictionary, or the dictionary has an unexpected format.
GL_ID_NOMODULE
The IME cannot find the module that is needed.
GL_ID_READINGCONFLICT
A reading conflict occurred. For example, some vowels cannot be put together to form one character.
GL_ID_TOOMANYSTROKE
There are too many strokes for one character or one clause.
GL_ID_TYPINGERROR
Typing error. The IME cannot handle this typing.
GL_ID_UNKNOWN
Unknown error. Refer to the error message string.
GL_ID_INPUTREADING
The IME is accepting reading character input from the end user.
GL_ID_INPUTRADICAL
The IME is accepting radical character input from the end user.
GL_ID_INPUTCODE
The IME is accepting character code input from the end user.
GL_ID_CHOOSECANDIDATE
The IME is accepting candidate string selection from the end user.
GL_ID_REVERSECONVERSION
Information about reverse conversion is available by calling ImmGetGuideLine, specifying GGL_PRIVATE. The information retrieved is in format.

returns.para: If dwIndex is GGL_STRING, the return value is the number of bytes of the string copied to the buffer. However, if dwBufLen is 0, the return value is the buffer size needed to receive the string, not including the terminating null character. For Unicode, if dwBufLen is 0, the return value is the size, in bytes not including the Unicode terminating null character.

If dwIndex is GGL_PRIVATE, the return value is the number of bytes of information copied to the buffer. If dwIndex is GGL_PRIVATE and dwBufLen is 0, the return value is the buffer size needed to receive the information.

remarks.para: Applications typically call this function after receiving an IMN_GUIDELINE command.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetGuideLine as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Retrieves the file name of the IME associated with the specified input locale.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: lpszFileName
param.para: Pointer to a buffer in which the function retrieves the file name. This parameter contains NULL when uBufLen is set to NULL.

param.name: uBufLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the output buffer. The application specifies 0 if the function is to return the buffer size needed to receive the file name, not including the terminating null character. For Unicode, uBufLen specifies the size in Unicode characters, not including the terminating null character.

returns.para: Returns the number of bytes in the file name copied to the output buffer. If the application sets uBufLen to 0, the function returns the size of the buffer required for the file name. In either case, the terminating null character is not included.
For Unicode, the function returns the number of Unicode characters copied into the output buffer, not including the Unicode terminating null character.

remarks.para: In the registry, the operating system stores the file name as the "IME name value" in the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\Keyboard Layouts\HKL.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetIMEFileName as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Retrieves the menu items that are registered in the IME menu of a specified input context.

param.name: unnamedParam1
param.para: Handle to the input context for the specified menu items.

param.name: unnamedParam2
param.para: Flag specifying menu information options. The following value is defined.

description.para: Retrieve the menu items for the context menu, obtained by a right mouse click.

param.name: unnamedParam3
param.para: Type of menu to retrieve. This parameter can have one or more of the following values.

description.para: Retrieve the menu items that control conversion mode.
Retrieve the menu items that control sentence mode.
Retrieve the menu items that are related to IME configuration.
Retrieve the menu items that are related to IME tools.
Retrieve the menu items that control IME Help.
Retrieve the menu items that control other IME functions.
Retrieve the menu items that control menu items related to IME input tools providing an extended way to input characters.

param.name: lpImeParentMenu
param.para: Pointer to an structure in which the function retrieves parent menu information. To retrieve information about the submenu items of this parent menu, the application sets the fType member to MFT_SUBMENU. This parameter contains NULL if the function retrieves only top-level menu items.

param.name: lpImeMenu
param.para: Pointer to an array of structures in which the function retrieves information about the menu items. This parameter contains NULL if the function retrieves the number of registered menu items.

param.name: dwSize
param.para: Size of the buffer to receive the structure.

returns.para: Returns the number of menu items copied into lpImeMenu. If lpImeMenu specifies NULL, the function returns the number of registered menu items in the specified input context.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetImeMenuItems as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Determines whether the IME is open or closed.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if the IME is open, or 0 otherwise.

summary.para: Retrieves the property and capabilities of the IME associated with the specified input locale.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Type of property information to retrieve. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Conversion capabilities.
System version number for which the specified IME was created.
Property information.
Selection inheritance capabilities.
Sentence mode capabilities.
Composition string capabilities.
User interface capabilities.

returns.para: Returns the property or capability value, depending on the value of the dwIndex parameter. If dwIndex is set to IGP_PROPERTY, the function returns one or more of the following values:

item.description: IME_PROP_AT_CARET
If set, conversion window is at the caret position. If clear, the window is near the caret position.
IME_PROP_SPECIAL_UI
If set, the IME has a nonstandard user interface. The application should not draw in the IME window.
IME_PROP_CANDLIST_START_FROM_1
If set, strings in the candidate list are numbered starting at 1. If clear, strings start at 0.
IME_PROP_UNICODE

If set, the IME is viewed as a Unicode IME. The operating system and the IME communicate through the Unicode IME interface. If clear, the IME uses the ANSI interface to communicate with the operating system.
IME_PROP_COMPLETE_ON_UNSELECT
If set, the IME completes the composition string when the IME is deactivated. If clear, the IME cancels the composition string when the IME is deactivated, for example, from a keyboard layout change.
IME_PROP_ACCEPT_WIDE_VKEY

If set, the IME processes the injected Unicode that came from the function by using VK_PACKET. If clear, the IME might not process the injected Unicode, and might send the injected Unicode to the application directly.

returns.para: If dwIndex is set to IGP_UI, the function returns one or more of the following values:

item.description: UI_CAP_2700
Support text escapement values of 0 or 2700. For more information, see the lfEscapement member of the structure.
UI_CAP_ROT90
Support text escapement values of 0, 900, 1800, or 2700. For more information, see lfEscapement.
UI_CAP_ROTANY
Support any text escapement value. For more information, see lfEscapement.

returns.para: If dwIndex is set to IGP_SETCOMPSTR, the function returns one or more of the following values:

item.description: SCS_CAP_COMPSTR
Create the composition string by calling the function with the SCS_SETSTR value.
SCS_CAP_MAKEREAD
Create the reading string from corresponding composition string when using the function with SCS_SETSTR and without setting lpRead.
SCS_CAP_SETRECONVERTSTRING:
This IME can support reconversion. Use to do reconversion.

returns.para: If dwIndex is set to IGP_SELECT, the function returns one or more of the following values:

item.description: SELECT_CAP_CONVMODE
Inherit conversion mode when a new IME is selected.
SELECT_CAP_SENTENCE
Inherit sentence mode when a new IME is selected.

returns.para: If dwIndex is set to IGP_GETIMEVERSION, the function returns one or more of the following values:

item.description: IMEVER_0310
The IME was created for Windows 3.1.
IMEVER_0400
The IME was created for Windows Me/98/95.

summary.para: Retrieves a list of the styles supported by the IME associated with the specified input locale.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: nItem
param.para: Maximum number of styles that the output buffer can hold. The application sets this parameter to 0 if the function is to count the number of styles available in the IME.

param.name: lpStyleBuf
param.para: Pointer to a structure in which the function retrieves the style information.

returns.para: Returns the number of styles copied to the buffer. If the application sets the nItem parameter to 0, the return value is the number of styles available in the IME.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmGetRegisterWordStyle as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Retrieves the position of the status window.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: lpptPos
param.para: Pointer to a POINT structure in which the function retrieves the position coordinates. These are screen coordinates, relative to the upper left corner of the screen.

summary.para: Retrieves the original virtual key value associated with a key input message that the IME has already processed.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to the window that receives the key message.

returns.para: If has been called by the application, ImmGetVirtualKey returns VK_PROCESSKEY; otherwise, it returns the virtual key.

remarks.para: Although the IME sets the virtual key value to VK_PROCESSKEY after processing a key input message, an application can recover the original virtual key value with the ImmGetVirtualKey function. This function is used only for key input messages containing the VK_PROCESSKEY value. Applications can only get the original virtual key by using this function after receiving
the WM_KEYDOWN (VK_PROCESSKEY) message, and before is called in its own
message loop.

summary.para: Checks for messages intended for the IME window and sends those messages to the window.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to a window belonging to the IME window class.

param.name: UINT
param.para: Message to check.

param.name: WPARAM
param.para: Message-specific parameter.

param.name: LPARAM
param.para: Message-specific parameter.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if the message is processed by the IME window, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: An application typically uses this function to display a composition string or candidate list specified by the IME. If hWndIME is NULL, the function determines if the message is a user interface message.

summary.para: Notifies the IME about changes to the status of the input context.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: dwAction
param.para: Notification code. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: An application changed the current selected candidate. The dwIndex parameter specifies an index of a candidate list to be selected and dwValue is not used.

An application directs the IME to close a candidate list. The dwIndex parameter specifies an index of the list to close, and dwValue is not used. The IME sends a IMN_CLOSECANDIDATE command to the application if it closes the list.
An application directs the IME to carry out an action on the composition string. The dwIndex parameter can be CPS_CANCEL, CPS_COMPLETE, CPS_CONVERT, or CPS_REVERT.

An application directs the IME to allow the application to handle the specified menu. The dwIndex parameter specifies the ID of the menu and dwValue is an application-defined value for that menu item.

An application directs the IME to open a candidate list. The dwIndex parameter specifies the index of the list to open, and dwValue is not used. The IME sends a IMN_OPENCANDIDATE command to the application if it opens the list.

An application has selected one of the candidates. The dwIndex parameter specifies an index of a candidate list to be selected. The dwValue parameter specifies an index of a candidate string in the selected candidate list.

The application changes the page size of a candidate list. The dwIndex parameter specifies the candidate list to be changed and must have a value in the range 0 to 3. The dwValue parameter specifies the new page size.

The application changes the page starting index of a candidate list. The dwIndex parameter specifies the candidate list to be changed and must have a value in the range 0 to 3. The dwValue parameter specifies the new page start index.

param.name: dwIndex
param.para: Index of a candidate list. Alternatively, if dwAction is NI_COMPOSITIONSTR, this parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Clear the composition string and set the status to no composition string.
Set the composition string as the result string.
Convert the composition string.
Cancel the current composition string and set the composition string to be the unconverted string.

param.name: dwValue
param.para: Index of a candidate string. The application can set this parameter or ignore it, depending on the value of the dwAction parameter.

returns.para: Returns nonzero if successful, or 0 otherwise.

summary.para: Registers a string with the dictionary of the IME associated with the specified input locale.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: lpszReading
param.para: Pointer to a null-terminated reading string associated with the string to register.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Style of the string to register. This parameter can have any of the following values.

description.para: The string is in the end-user-defined (EUDC) range.

description.b: Any value in the range from IME_REGWORD_STYLE_USER_FIRST to IME_REGWORD_STYLE_USER_LAST

description.para: The string has a private style maintained by the specified IME. See the Remarks section for more details.

param.name: lpszRegister
param.para: Pointer to the null-terminated string to register.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: An IME independent software vendor (ISV) can define private styles for an IME in the IME_REGWORD_STYLE_USER_FIRST and IME_REGWORD_STYLE_USER_LAST values. For example:

Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

summary.para: Sets information about the candidates window.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: lpCandidate
param.para: Pointer to a structure that contains information about the candidates window.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: This function causes an IMN_SETCANDIDATEPOS command to be sent. Both the IME and the application call this function.

summary.para: Sets the logical font to use to display characters in the composition window.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: lplf
param.para: Pointer to a structure containing the font information to set.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: This function causes a IMN_SETCOMPOSITIONFONT command to be sent to an application. Even if the application never uses the composition window, it must set the appropriate font to ensure that characters are displayed properly. This is especially true for vertical writing.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmSetCompositionFont as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Sets the characters, attributes, and clauses of the composition and reading strings.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: dwIndex
param.para: Type of information to set. This parameter can have one of the following values.

description.para: Set the composition string, the reading string, or both. At least one of the lpComp and lpRead parameters must indicate a valid string. If either string is too long, the IME truncates it.
Set attributes for the composition string, the reading string, or both. At least one of the lpComp and lpRead parameters must indicate a valid attribute array.
Set the clause information for the composition string, the reading string, or both. At least one of the lpComp and lpRead parameters must point to a valid clause information array.

item.description: Windows Me/98, Windows 2000, Windows XP: Ask IME to reconvert the string using a specified structure.

Windows Me/98, Windows 2000, Windows XP: Ask IME to adjust the structure. Then the application can pass the adjusted structure into this function using SCS_SETRECONVERTSTRING. IME does not generate any WM_IME_COMPOSITION messages.

param.name: lpComp
param.para: Pointer to a buffer containing the information to set for the composition string, as specified by the value of dwIndex.

param.name: dwCompLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the information buffer for the composition string, even if SCS_SETSTR is specified and the buffer contains a Unicode string.

param.name: lpRead
param.para: Pointer to a buffer containing the information to set for the reading string, as specified by the value of dwIndex. The application can set this parameter to NULL.

param.name: dwReadLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the information buffer for the reading string, even if SCS_SETSTR is specified and the buffer contains a Unicode string.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: The application can set lpComp, lpRead, or both. If the application does not specify a value for lpComp, it must set this parameter to NULL and set dwCompLen to 0.

When the application is changing attributes, all characters in a clause must have the same attribute. Converted characters must have the attribute ATTR_CONVERTED or ATTR_TARGET_CONVERTED. Unconverted characters must have the attribute ATTR_INPUT or ATTR_TARGET_NOTCONVERTED.

When the application is changing clause information, it can change only the target clause, just affecting one boundary at a time. The target clause has the attribute ATTR_TARGET_CONVERTED or ATTR_TARGET_NOTCONVERTED.
For additional information about attributes (ATTR_* values), see Composition String.
When the IME completes the changes, it sends a WM_IME_COMPOSITION message to the application to notify it of the changes.

Windows Me/98, Windows 2000, Windows XP: The SCS_*CONVERTSTRING values are used for reconversion. They can only be used for an IME that has the SCS_CAP_SETRECONVERTSTRING property. The application uses these values as follows:

item.description: Call ImmSetCompositionString with SCS_QUERYRECONVERTSTRING, so that IME adjusts the structure for the reconversion.

Call ImmSetCompositionString with SCS_SETRECONVERTSTRING, so that IME generates a new composition string. After this, lpComp and lpRead indicate a structure that contains the updated composition and reading string. Use the value of lpRead only when the selected IME has SCS_CAP_MAKEREAD set.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmSetCompositionString as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

item.description: Windows Me/98, Windows 2000, Windows XP: Ask IME to reconvert the string using a specified structure.

Windows Me/98, Windows 2000, Windows XP: Ask IME to adjust the structure. Then the application can pass the adjusted structure into this function using SCS_SETRECONVERTSTRING. IME does not generate any WM_IME_COMPOSITION messages.

param.name: lpComp
param.para: Pointer to a buffer containing the information to set for the composition string, as specified by the value of dwIndex.

param.name: dwCompLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the information buffer for the composition string, even if SCS_SETSTR is specified and the buffer contains a Unicode string.

param.name: lpRead
param.para: Pointer to a buffer containing the information to set for the reading string, as specified by the value of dwIndex. The application can set this parameter to NULL.

param.name: dwReadLen
param.para: Size, in bytes, of the information buffer for the reading string, even if SCS_SETSTR is specified and the buffer contains a Unicode string.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: The application can set lpComp, lpRead, or both. If the application does not specify a value for lpComp, it must set this parameter to NULL and set dwCompLen to 0.

When the application is changing attributes, all characters in a clause must have the same attribute. Converted characters must have the attribute ATTR_CONVERTED or ATTR_TARGET_CONVERTED. Unconverted characters must have the attribute ATTR_INPUT or ATTR_TARGET_NOTCONVERTED.

When the application is changing clause information, it can change only the target clause, just affecting one boundary at a time. The target clause has the attribute ATTR_TARGET_CONVERTED or ATTR_TARGET_NOTCONVERTED.
For additional information about attributes (ATTR_* values), see Composition String.
When the IME completes the changes, it sends a WM_IME_COMPOSITION message to the application to notify it of the changes.

Windows Me/98, Windows 2000, Windows XP: The SCS_*CONVERTSTRING values are used for reconversion. They can only be used for an IME that has the SCS_CAP_SETRECONVERTSTRING property. The application uses these values as follows:

item.description: Call ImmSetCompositionString with SCS_QUERYRECONVERTSTRING, so that IME adjusts the structure for the reconversion.

Call ImmSetCompositionString with SCS_SETRECONVERTSTRING, so that IME generates a new composition string. After this, lpComp and lpRead indicate a structure that contains the updated composition and reading string. Use the value of lpRead only when the selected IME has SCS_CAP_MAKEREAD set.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmSetCompositionString as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.

summary.para: Sets the position of the composition window.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: lpCompForm
param.para: Pointer to a structure that contains the new position and other related information about the composition window.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: This function causes an IMN_SETCOMPOSITIONWINDOW command to be sent to the application.

summary.para: Sets the current conversion status.

param.name: unnamedParam1
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: unnamedParam2
param.para: Conversion mode values. For more information, see IME Conversion Mode Values.

param.name: unnamedParam3
param.para: Sentence mode values. For more information, see IME Sentence Mode Values.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: This function sends the IMN_SETCONVERSIONMODE and IMN_SETSENTENCEMODE commands to the application.

Note Beginning with Windows 8: By default, the input switch is set per user instead of per thread. The Microsoft IME (Japanese) respects the mode globally, and therefore ImmSetConversionStatus fails when getting focus.

summary.para: Opens or closes the IME.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: BOOL
param.para: TRUE if the IME is open, or FALSE if it is closed.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: This function causes an IMN_SETOPENSTATUS command to be sent to the application.

summary.para: Sets the position of the status window.

param.name: HIMC
param.para: Handle to the input context.

param.name: lpptPos
param.para: Pointer to a POINT structure containing the new position of the status window, in screen coordinates relative to the upper left corner of the display screen.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

remarks.para: This function causes an IMN_SETSTATUSWINDOWPOS command to be sent to the application.

summary.para: Simulates the specified IME hot key, causing the same response as if the user presses the hot key in the specified window.

param.name: HWND
param.para: Handle to the window.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Identifier of the IME hot key. For more information, see IME Hot Key Identifiers.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

summary.para: Removes a register string from the dictionary of the IME associated with the specified input locale.

param.name: HKL
param.para: Input locale identifier.

param.name: lpszReading
param.para: Pointer to a null-terminated reading string associated with the string to remove.

param.name: DWORD
param.para: Style of the register string. This parameter can have any of the following values.

description.para: The string is in the end-user-defined character (EUDC) range.

description.b: Any value from IME_REGWORD_STYLE_USER_FIRST to IME_REGWORD_STYLE_USER_LAST

description.para: The string is in a private style maintained by the specified IME.

param.name: lpszUnregister
param.para: Pointer to a null-terminated string specifying the register string to remove.

returns.para: Returns a nonzero value if successful, or 0 otherwise.

blockquote.para: [!NOTE] The immdev.h header defines ImmUnregisterWord as an alias which automatically selects the ANSI or Unicode version of this function based on the definition of the UNICODE preprocessor constant. Mixing usage of the encoding-neutral alias with code that not encoding-neutral can lead to mismatches that result in compilation or runtime errors. For more information, see Conventions for Function Prototypes.
